25.verse: If the officials hear that I have talked with you, and they come to you and say, ‘Tell us now what you said to the king; don’t hide it from us, or we will put you to death, and also what the king said to you,’

26.verse: then tell them, ‘I presented my request to the king that he would not make me return to Y’honatan’s house, to die there.’”

27.verse: All the officials did come to Yirmeyahu and asked him, and he told them everything the king had ordered him to say. So they stopped speaking with him, since the matter had not been reported.

28.verse: Yirmeyahu remained in the guards’ quarters until the day Yerushalayim was captured; he was there when Yerushalayim was captured.

1.verse: In the ninth year of Tzidkiyahu king of Y’hudah, in the tenth month, N’vukhadretzar king of Bavel marched against Yerushalayim with his entire army and began to lay siege against it.

2.verse: On the ninth day of the fourth month of the eleventh year of Tzidkiyahu, they broke through into the city.

3.verse: All the officers of the king of Bavel entered and sat at the Middle Gate — Nergal-Sar’etzer, Samgar-N’vo, Sars’khim the Rav-Saris, Nergal-Sar’etzer the Rav-Mag and all the other officers of the king of Bavel.

4.verse: When Tzidkiyahu the king of Y’hudah and all the soldiers saw them, they fled, leaving the city by night through the king’s garden, exiting from the gate between the two walls, and continuing out by the route through the ‘Aravah.

5.verse: But the army of the Kasdim went in pursuit of them and overtook Tzidkiyahu on the plains near Yericho. Upon capturing him, they brought him up to N’vukhadretzar king of Bavel at Rivlah, in the land of Hamat, where he passed judgment on him.

6.verse: The king of Bavel slaughtered the sons of Tzidkiyahu before his eyes in Rivlah; the king of Bavel also slaughtered all the leading men of Y’hudah.

7.verse: Then he put out Tzidkiyahu’s eyes and bound him in chains to be carried off to Bavel.

8.verse: The Kasdim burned down the royal palace and the people’s houses, and they broke down the walls of Yerushalayim.

9.verse: N’vuzar’adan commander of the guard then deported to Bavel the remaining population of the city, the deserters who had defected to him, and the rest of the people remaining.

10.verse: But N’vuzar’adan the commander of the guard left behind in the territory of Y’hudah some of the poor people, those who had nothing, and at the same time gave them vineyards and fields.

11.verse: Concerning Yirmeyahu, N’vukhadretzar king of Bavel gave N’vuzar’adan the commander of the guard this order:

12.verse: “Take him, look after him well, and do him no harm, but treat him as he tells you.”

13.verse: So N’vuzar’adan the commander of the guard, N’vushazban the Rav-Saris, Nergal-Sar’etzer the Rav-Mag, and all the chief officers of the king of Bavel

14.verse: sent to have Yirmeyahu taken out of the guards’ quarters; they committed him to the care of G’dalyahu the son of Achikam, the son of Shafan, to be brought home. There he lived among the people.

15.verse: This word of ADONAI came to Yirmeyahu while he was imprisoned in the guards’ quarters:

16.verse: “Go and tell ‘Eved-Melekh the Ethiopian that ADONAI-Tzva’ot, the God of Isra’el, says: ‘“I am about to fulfill my words about this city for disaster, not for good; when the day arrives, they will come true before your eyes.

17.verse: But at that time I will rescue you,” says ADONAI, “and I will not hand you over to the men you fear.

18.verse: Yes, I will keep you safe; you will not fall by the sword, but you will escape with your life, because you have put your trust in me,” says ADONAI.’”

1.verse: This word came to Yirmeyahu from ADONAI after N’vuzar’adan the commander of the guard had let him leave Ramah, after having taken him, bound in chains, with all the captives from Yerushalayim and Y’hudah that had been carried off to Bavel.

2.verse: The commander of the guard took Yirmeyahu and said to him, “ADONAI your God decreed this disaster for this place,

3.verse: and ADONAI has brought it about; he has done what he said he would do, because you people sinned against ADONAI and did not listen to what he said; that is why this has come upon you.

4.verse: Now, today, I am freeing you from the chains on your hand. If it seems good to you to come with me to Bavel, come; and I will look after you well. But if it seems not good to you to come with me to Bavel, then don’t — the entire land is in front of you: wherever it seems good and right for you to go, go there.”

5.verse: Before Yirmeyahu could answer, [N’vuzar’adan said,] “Go back then to G’dalyahu the son of Achikam, the son of Shafan, whom the king of Bavel has made governor over the cities of Y’hudah, and live with him among the people; or go wherever it seems right for you to go.” The commander of the guard gave him provisions and a gift, and dismissed him.

6.verse: Yirmeyahu then went to G’dalyahu the son of Achikam in Mitzpah and lived with him among the people who were left in the land.

7.verse: Now when all the field force commanders and their men heard that the king of Bavel had made G’dalyahu the son of Achikam governor in the land and had committed to his care men, women, children and some of the poorest people in the land of those who had not been carried captive to Bavel;

8.verse: they approached G’dalyahu in Mitzpah — in particular, Yishma‘el the son of N’tanyahu, Yochanan and Yonatan the sons of Kareach, S’rayah the son of Tanchumet, the sons of ‘Efai the N’tofati and Y’zanyahu the son of the Ma‘akhati, they and their men.

9.verse: G’dalyahu the son of Achikam, the son of Shafan, swore to them and their men, “Don’t be afraid to serve the Kasdim. Live in the land, serve the king of Bavel; and things will go well with you.

10.verse: As for me, I will live in Mitzpah and be responsible to the Kasdim who come to us. But you — harvest wine, summer fruits and olive oil; put them in your containers; and live in your cities that you have taken over.”

11.verse: Likewise, when all the Judeans who were in Mo’av, in Edom, among the people of ‘Amon, and in all the other countries heard that the king of Bavel had left a remnant in Y’hudah and had appointed G’dalyahu the son of Achikam, the son of Shafan, to govern them;

12.verse: then all the Judeans returned from all the places where they had been driven and came to the land of Y’hudah, to G’dalyahu in Mitzpah, and harvested wine and summer fruit in great abundance.

13.verse: Yochanan the son of Kareach and all the field force commanders came to G’dalyahu in Mitzpah

14.verse: and said to him, “Are you aware that Ba‘alis the king of the people of ‘Amon has sent Yishma‘el the son of N’tanyahu to take your life?” But G’dalyahu the son of Achikam did not believe them.

15.verse: Then Yochanan the son of Kareach spoke privately with G’dalyahu in Mitzpah: “Please, let me go, and I will kill Yishma‘el the son of N’tanyahu; no one will know. Why let him assassinate you? Moreover, if he does, all the Judeans gathered around you will scatter; and the remnant of Y’hudah will perish.”

16.verse: But G’dalyahu the son of Achikam said to Yochanan the son of Kareach, “Don’t do it. What you are saying about Yishma‘el is not true.”

1.verse: In the seventh month Yishma‘el the son of N’tanyahu, the son of Elishama, of royal blood and one of the chief officials of the king, came with ten men to G’dalyahu in Mitzpah. While eating a meal together there in Mitzpah,

2.verse: Yishma‘el and the ten men with him rose and attacked G’dalyahu the son of Achikam, the son of Shafan, struck him with their swords, and assassinated the man whom the king of Bavel had appointed governor of the land.

3.verse: Yishma‘el also murdered all the Judeans who were with G’dalyahu at Mitzpah, as well as the Kasdim soldiers they found there.

4.verse: The next day, before his assassination of G’dalyahu had become known,

5.verse: eighty men from Sh’khem, Shiloh and Shomron came with beards shaved off, clothes torn and gashes on their bodies; they had grain offerings and frankincense with them to present in the house of ADONAI.

6.verse: Yishma‘el the son of N’tanyahu went out from Mitzpah to meet them, weeping all along the way; on meeting them, he said to them, “Come to G’dalyahu the son of Achikam.”

7.verse: But once they were inside the city, Yishma‘el the son of N’tanyahu and the men with him slaughtered them and threw them into the cistern.

8.verse: However, ten of them said to Yishma‘el, “Don’t kill us, for we have stores of wheat, barley, olive oil and honey hidden in the field.” So he relented, and did not kill them along with their comrades.

9.verse: The cistern in which Yishma‘el threw the corpses of the men he had murdered with G’dalyahu was the one Asa the king had made in fear of Ba‘asha king of Isra’el; it was this cistern that Yishma‘el the son of N’tanyahu filled with the slaughtered men.

10.verse: Then Yishma‘el carried off captive the rest of the people in Mitzpah — the king’s daughters and all the people left in Mitzpah, whom N’vuzar’adan the commander of the guard had committed to the care of G’dalyahu the son of Achikam. Yishma‘el the son of N’tanyahu carried them off captive and left to cross over to the people of ‘Amon.

11.verse: When Yochanan the son of Kareach and all the military commanders with him heard of all the crimes committed by Yishma‘el the son of N’tanyahu,

12.verse: they took all the men and went to attack Yishma‘el the son of N’tanyahu. They found him by the big pool in Giv‘on.

13.verse: When all Yishma‘el’s captives saw Yochanan the son of Kareach and all the military commanders with him, they were overjoyed.

14.verse: So all the people Yishma‘el had carried off captive from Mitzpah turned and joined Yochanan the son of Kareach.

15.verse: But Yishma‘el the son of N’tanyahu escaped from Yochanan with eight men and went on to the people of ‘Amon.

16.verse: Yochanan the son of Kareach and the military commanders with him then took all the rest of the people he had freed from Yishma‘el the son of N’tanyahu, those Yishma‘el had taken from Mitzpah after assassinating G’dalyahu the son of Achikam — the heroes, the soldiers, the women, the children and the officers he had brought back from Giv‘on —

17.verse: and they left there to stay at Kimham’s Lodge, near Beit-Lechem, intending to go on to Egypt

18.verse: and thus escape the Kasdim. They were afraid of them, because Yishma‘el the son of N’tanyahu had murdered G’dalyahu the son of Achikam, whom the king of Bavel had appointed governor of the land.

1.verse: Then all the military commanders, Yochanan the son of Kareach, Y’zanyah the son of Hosha‘yah and all the people, from the least to the greatest, approached

2.verse: and said to Yirmeyahu the prophet, “I beg you, approve our request: pray for us to ADONAI your God for all of this remnant. For, while once we were numerous, only a few of us are left, as you can see.

3.verse: Pray that ADONAI your God will tell us what direction to take and what to do.”

4.verse: Yirmeyahu the prophet said to them: “I hear you. All right, I will pray to ADONAI your God, as you have asked. And whatever ADONAI answers you, I will tell you; I will withhold nothing from you.”

5.verse: They said to Yirmeyahu, “May ADONAI be a true and faithful witness against us if we fail to do any part of what ADONAI your God gives you to tell us.

6.verse: Whether it be good or bad, we will listen to what ADONAI our God says. We are dispatching you to him so that things will go well with us, as we heed what ADONAI our God says.”

7.verse: Ten days later the word of ADONAI came to Yirmeyahu.

8.verse: So he called Yochanan the son of Kareach, all the military commanders with him and all the people, from the least to the greatest,

9.verse: and said to them, “You sent me to present your request to ADONAI the God of Isra’el. This is what he says:

10.verse: ‘If you will stay in this land, then I will build you up, not pull you down; I will plant you and not uproot you; for I am relenting from the calamity I inflicted on you.

11.verse: Don’t be afraid of the king of Bavel — of whom you are afraid. Don’t be afraid of him,’ says ADONAI, ‘for I am with you to save you and to rescue you from his power.

12.verse: I will take pity on you, so that he will take pity on you and cause you to return to your own land.

13.verse: “But if you say, ‘We will not stay in this land,’ thereby not heeding what ADONAI your God is saying,

14.verse: and instead say, ‘No, we will go to the land of Egypt; because there we will not see war or hear the shofar sounding its alarm or be short of food; so we’ll stay there’;

15.verse: then hear what ADONAI says, remnant of Y’hudah — this is what ADONAI-Tzva’ot, the God of Isra’el, says: ‘If you are determined to go to Egypt and stay there,

16.verse: the sword, of which you are afraid, will overtake you there in the land of Egypt; and the famine, of which you are afraid, will pursue you relentlessly there in Egypt; and there you will die.

17.verse: This is how it will be for all the people determined to go to Egypt and stay there — they will die by sword, famine and plague; none of them will remain or escape the disaster that I will bring upon them.’

18.verse: For here is what ADONAI-Tzva’ot, the God of Isra’el, says: ‘Just as my anger and fury were poured out on the inhabitants of Yerushalayim, so likewise my fury will be poured out on you if you go to Egypt; so that you will become an object of condemnation, astonishment, cursing and reproach; and you will see this place no more.’

19.verse: “ADONAI has spoken concerning you, remnant of Y’hudah! Don’t go to Egypt! You know for a fact that I have given you fair warning today.

20.verse: For you have been behaving deceitfully, against your own interests. You sent me to ADONAI your God, saying, ‘Pray for us to ADONAI our God; tell us everything ADONAI our God says, and we will do it.’

21.verse: Today I have told it to you, but you haven’t heeded any part of what ADONAI your God gave me to tell you.

22.verse: Therefore, know for a fact that you will die by sword, famine and plague in the place where you want to go and live.”

1.verse: When Yirmeyahu had finished telling all the people everything ADONAI their God had said, which ADONAI their God had sent him to tell them, the entire speech cited above,

2.verse: then ‘Azaryah the son of Hosha‘yah, Yochanan the son of Kareach and all the men with him had the effrontery to say to Yirmeyahu, “You are lying! ADONAI our God did not send you to say, ‘Don’t go to Egypt and live there’!

3.verse: Rather, Barukh the son of Neriyah is inciting you against us, so that we can be handed over to the Kasdim to be put to death or carried off as captives to Bavel.”

4.verse: So Yochanan the son of Kareach, all the military commanders and all the people did not heed what ADONAI said, to live in the land of Y’hudah.

5.verse: Instead, Yochanan the son of Kareach and all the military commanders took all the remnant of Y’hudah who had returned from all the nations where they had been driven to live in the land of Y’hudah —

6.verse: the men, the women, the children, the king’s daughters, everyone N’vuzar’adan the commander of the guard had committed to G’dalyahu the son of Achikam, the son of Shafan, and Yirmeyahu the prophet and Barukh the son of Neriyah —

7.verse: and went to the land of Egypt; for they did not heed what ADONAI had said; and they arrived in Tachpanches.

8.verse: Then this word of ADONAI came to Yirmeyahu in Tachpanches:

9.verse: “With the men of Y’hudah watching, take some big stones, and set them with mortar in the pavement at the entry to Pharaoh’s palace in Tachpanches.

10.verse: Tell them: ‘This is what ADONAI-Tzva’ot, the God of Isra’el, says: “I will summon N’vukhadretzar the king of Bavel, my servant, take him and set his throne on these stones I laid here; he will come and spread his royal canopy over them.

11.verse: He will come and attack the land of Egypt. Those destined for death — to death! Those destined for captivity — to captivity! Those destined for the sword — to the sword!

12.verse: I will light a fire in the temples of the gods of Egypt, and he will burn [those gods] or take them captive. He will fold up the land of Egypt like a shepherd folding up his cloak, and leave there victorious.

13.verse: He will also break the standing-stones of the temple of the sun in the land of Egypt and burn to the ground the temples of the gods of Egypt.”’”

1.verse: This word came to Yirmeyahu concerning all the people from Y’hudah living in the land of Egypt — in Migdol, Tachpanches, Nof and the land of Patros:

2.verse: “Here is what ADONAI-Tzva’ot, the God of Isra’el, says: ‘You have seen all the disaster I inflicted on Yerushalayim and all the cities of Y’hudah; there they are today, ruined, with no one living in them.

3.verse: It came about because of the wicked things they did to make me angry — sacrificing to and serving other gods, whom they did not know, neither they, nor you nor your ancestors.

4.verse: I had sent you all my servants the prophets, sent them frequently, with the message, “Don’t do this horrible thing which I hate!”

5.verse: But they neither listened nor obeyed, so as to turn from their wickedness and stop offering to other gods.

6.verse: Hence my fury and anger were poured out and ignited in the cities of Y’hudah and the streets of Yerushalayim; so that they became waste and desolate, as they are today.’

7.verse: “Therefore now, ADONAI-Tzva’ot, the God of Isra’el, says this: ‘Why are you committing this great sin against yourselves? The result can only be to cut you off from Y’hudah — men, women, children and babies — so that none of you remain.

8.verse: For you continue provoking me with the products of your own hands, offering to other gods in the land of Egypt, where you have gone to live as aliens. It will lead only to your destruction and becoming an object of curses and reproaches among all the nations of the earth.

9.verse: Have you forgotten the wicked deeds of your ancestors, the wicked deeds of the kings of Y’hudah, the wicked deeds of their wives, your own wicked deeds, and the wicked deeds of your wives, which they committed in the land of Y’hudah and in the streets of Yerushalayim?

10.verse: To this day they remain unhumbled; they have not been afraid, and they have not lived according to my Torah or my regulations that I presented to you and your ancestors.’

11.verse: “Therefore here is what ADONAI-Tzva’ot, the God of Isra’el, says: ‘I will decree disaster for you and destroy all of Y’hudah.

12.verse: I will take the remnant of Y’hudah, who determined to go to Egypt and live there as aliens, and they will all perish — in the land of Egypt they will fall and perish by sword and famine. They will die, from the least to the greatest, by sword and famine; and they will become an object of condemnation, astonishment, cursing and reproach.

13.verse: Yes, I will punish those living in the land of Egypt, as I punished Yerushalayim, by sword, famine and plague;

14.verse: so that none of the remnant of Y’hudah who went into the land of Egypt to live as aliens will escape or remain, to be able to return to the land of Y’hudah. They long to return and live there, but none will return except a few refugees.’”

15.verse: Then all the men who knew that their wives were offering incense to other gods, along with all the women standing by, a huge crowd, all the people living in Patros in the land of Egypt, answered Yirmeyahu:

16.verse: “As for the word you have just spoken to us in the name of ADONAI, we will not listen to you.

17.verse: Instead, we will certainly continue to fulfill every word our mouths have spoken: we will offer incense to the queen of heaven and pour out drink offerings to her, as we have done, we and our ancestors, our kings and our leaders, in the cities of Y’hudah and the streets of Yerushalayim. For then we had plenty of food; everything was fine, we didn’t experience anything unpleasant.

18.verse: But since we stopped offering to the queen of heaven and pouring out drink offerings to her, we have lacked everything, and we have been destroyed by sword and famine.”

19.verse: [Then the wives added,] “Are we the ones who offer incense to the queen of heaven? Do we pour out drink offerings to her? And did we make cakes marked with her image for her and pour out drink offerings to her without our husbands’ consent?”

20.verse: Then Yirmeyahu said to all the people — to the men, the women, and all the people who had answered him back:

21.verse: “The incense you offered in the cities of Y’hudah and in the streets of Yerushalayim — you, your ancestors, your kings, your leaders and the people of the land — ADONAI kept remembering and taking note of this [insult],

22.verse: until ADONAI could no longer bear it, so evil and so detestable were your deeds. This is why your land has become a wasteland, an object for astonishment and cursing, uninhabited, as it is today.

23.verse: It is because you offered incense, sinned against ADONAI, didn’t listen to what ADONAI said, and didn’t live by his Torah, regulations and instructions that this disaster has befallen you, as it is today.”

24.verse: In addition, Yirmeyahu said to all the people, but especially the women: “Hear the word of ADONAI, all Y’hudah who are in the land of Egypt;

25.verse: this is what ADONAI-Tzva’ot, the God of Isra’el, says: ‘You and your wives stated your intentions with your mouths and performed them with your hands — you said, “We will certainly fulfill our vows that we made to offer incense to the queen of heaven and pour out drink offerings to her.”’ Without doubt, you will indeed fulfill every point of your vows.

26.verse: Therefore hear the word of ADONAI, all Y’hudah living in the land of Egypt: ‘I swear by my own great name,’ says ADONAI, ‘that no man of Y’hudah will speak my name again in the land of Egypt, swearing, “As ADONAI, God, lives.”

27.verse: I am watching over them for harm, not for good. All the men of Y’hudah in the land of Egypt will be destroyed by sword and famine, until none of them is left.

28.verse: Those who escape the sword will return from the land of Egypt to the land of Y’hudah few in number; and all the remnant of Y’hudah who went into the land of Egypt to live will know whose word will stand — mine or theirs!

29.verse: Moreover, here is a sign for you,’ says ADONAI, ‘that I will punish you in this place, so that you can know that my threats of disaster against you will come true.’

30.verse: ADONAI says, ‘I will hand over Pharaoh Hofra king of Egypt to his enemies, to those seeking his life — just as I handed Tzidkiyahu king of Y’hudah over to N’vukhadretzar king of Bavel, his enemy, who sought his life.’”

1.verse: Here is what Yirmeyahu said to Barukh the son of Neriyah when he wrote these words in a book at Yirmeyahu’s dictation, in the fourth year of Y’hoyakim the son of Yoshiyahu, king of Y’hudah:

2.verse: “This is what Adonai the God of Isra’el says concerning you, Barukh. You said,

3.verse: ‘Woe to me now! ADONAI has compounded my pain with sorrow, I am weary from groaning, and I can find no relief!’

4.verse: “Tell him that ADONAI says: ‘I will tear down what I built up, I will uproot what I planted, and this throughout the land.

5.verse: Are you seeking great things for yourself? Don’t! For I am bringing disaster on everything living,’ says ADONAI. ‘But wherever you go, you will escape with your life.’”

1.verse: This is the word of ADONAI that came to Yirmeyahu the prophet concerning the nations.

2.verse: Concerning Egypt, against the army of Pharaoh N’kho, king of Egypt, stationed by the Euphrates River in Kark’mish, which N’vukhadretzar king of Bavel attacked in the fourth year of Y’hoyakim son of Yoshiyahu, king of Y’hudah:

3.verse: “Prepare breastplate and shield! Advance to battle!

4.verse: Harness the horses! Riders, mount! [Troops,] fall in! Helmets in place! Polish the spears! Coats of mail on!

5.verse: “Why do I see them retreating in panic, their heroes routed, fleeing headlong, not looking back, terror all around?” asks ADONAI.

6.verse: “The swift cannot flee, nor the heroes escape. In the north, by the Euphrates River, they have stumbled and fallen.”

7.verse: Who is this, rising up like the Nile, like rivers whose waters surge out in flood?

8.verse: It is Egypt, rising up like the Nile, like rivers whose waters surge out in flood, saying, “I will surge out and cover the earth, destroying the city along with its people.”

9.verse: Charge, horses! Full speed ahead, chariots! Let the warriors attack! — Kush and Put, bearing their shields, and the Ludim, strung bows in hand.

10.verse: For on that day Adonai ELOHEI-Tzva’ot will have a day of vengeance for avenging himself on his enemies. The sword will destroy, have its fill, be made drunk on their blood. Yes, Adonai ELOHEI-Tzva’ot decrees slaughter in the land to the north by the Euphrates River.

11.verse: Go up to Gil‘ad for its healing resin, virgin daughter of Egypt. You try many medicines, all in vain; for you there is no cure.

12.verse: The nations have heard about your disgrace; your shrieks fill the earth as warrior trips over warrior, both falling down together.

13.verse: This word ADONAI spoke to Yirmeyahu the prophet concerning how N’vukhadretzar king of Bavel would come and attack the land of Egypt:

14.verse: “Proclaim in Egypt, announce in Migdol, announce in Nof and Tachpanches; say: ‘Take your stand! Get ready! For all around you the sword is destroying.

15.verse: Why has your strong one been overthrown? He failed to stand because ADONAI pushed him down.

16.verse: He caused many to trip; yes, they fell all over each other.’” Then they said, “Let’s get up, let’s return to our own people, back to the land where we were born, away from the sword that destroys.”

17.verse: They cried there, “Pharaoh king of Egypt makes noise, but he lets the right time [for action] slip by.”

18.verse: “As I live,” says the king, whose name is ADONAI-Tzva’ot, “when he comes, he will be [as mighty] as Tavor among the mountains, as Karmel next to the sea.

19.verse: “Daughter living in Egypt, prepare what you need for exile; for Nof will become a ruin, laid waste, without inhabitant.

20.verse: Egypt is a beautiful female calf; but a horsefly from the north has come to attack her.

21.verse: Her mercenaries too, that she had with her, were like well-fed calves in a stable; but they too have withdrawn in retreat, they all ran away without standing their ground. For their day of disaster has come over them, the time for them to be punished.

22.verse: Egypt hisses like a snake, as the enemy’s army marches ahead, attacking her with their axes like lumbermen chopping trees.

23.verse: They cut down her forest,” says ADONAI, “for they cannot be numbered; yes, there are more of them than locusts, far too many to count.

24.verse: The daughter of Egypt is put to shame, handed over to the people from the north.”

25.verse: ADONAI-Tzva’ot, the God of Isra’el, says: “I will punish Amon from No, Pharaoh, and Egypt with her gods and kings — that is, Pharaoh and those who trust in him;

26.verse: I will hand them over to those who seek their lives, to N’vukhadretzar king of Bavel and to his servants. But afterwards, Egypt will be inhabited, as in the past,” says ADONAI.

27.verse: “Yet don’t be afraid, Ya‘akov my servant; don’t be distressed, Isra’el. For I will save you from faraway places, and your offspring from the lands where they are held captive. Ya‘akov will return and be at peace, quiet, with no one to make him afraid.

28.verse: Don’t be afraid, Ya‘akov my servant,” says ADONAI, “for I am with you. I will finish off all the nations where I have scattered you. However, you I will not finish off, I will discipline you as you deserve, but not completely destroy you.”

1.verse: This word of ADONAI came to Yirmeyahu the prophet concerning the P’lishtim before Pharaoh attacked ‘Azah:

2.verse: “Here is what ADONAI says: ‘Water is rising out of the north; it will become a flooding stream, flooding the land and all that is in it, the city and its inhabitants. The people are crying out in alarm, everyone in the land is weeping

3.verse: at the thunderous pound of his stallions’ hoofs, at his rattling chariots’ rumbling wheels. Fathers fail to turn back for their children; instead, their hands hang limp,

4.verse: because the day has come for destroying all the P’lishtim, for cutting off from Tzor and Tzidon the last of their allies; for ADONAI is destroying the P’lishtim, the remnant from the island of Kaftor.

5.verse: ‘Azah is shaved bald, Ashkelon reduced to silence. Those of you who remain in their valley, how long will you go on gashing yourselves?’”

6.verse: Oh, sword of ADONAI, how long till you can be quiet? Put yourself back in your scabbard! Stop! Be still!

7.verse: But how can you be still? For ADONAI has given it orders against Ashkelon, against the seacoast; he has assigned it its task there.

1.verse: Concerning Mo’av, this is what ADONAI-Tzva’ot, the God of Isra’el, says: “Woe to N’vo, for it is ravaged; Kiryatayim disgraced and captured. Misgav is put to shame, distressed.

2.verse: “In Mo’av, nothing is left to praise. At Heshbon they plotted her downfall: ‘Come, we’ll cut her off as a nation.’ You too, Madmein, will be silenced; the sword pursues behind you.

3.verse: An agonized cry from Horonayim, ruin, terrible devastation!

4.verse: Mo’av has been shattered; the cries of her young ones are heard,

5.verse: as they ascend the slopes of Luchit, weeping bitterly as they climb. On the road down to Horonayim shrieks of destruction ring out.”

6.verse: Flee! Save your lives! Be strong, like a tamarisk in the desert.

7.verse: Because you trust in your deeds and your wealth, you too will be captured. Together with his priests and princes, K’mosh will go into exile.

8.verse: A destroyer will descend on every city, no city will escape. The valley too will perish, the plain will be laid waste, as ADONAI as said.

9.verse: Give Mo’av wings, so it can fly and get away. Its cities will become ruins, with no one to live in them.

10.verse: A curse on him who does the work of ADONAI carelessly! A curse on him who withholds his sword from blood!

11.verse: Mo’av has lived at ease from his youth; he is [wine] settled on its dregs, not decanted from jar to jar — he has not gone into exile. Therefore it retains its own [bad] taste, its aroma remains unchanged.

12.verse: “So the days are coming,” says ADONAI, “when I will send people to tilt him; they will tilt his jars, emptying them and shattering the wine-flasks to pieces.

13.verse: Mo’av will be disappointed by K’mosh then, just as the house of Isra’el was disappointed by Beit-El, a god in whom they had put their trust.

14.verse: “How can you say, ‘We are heroes, warriors valiant in battle’?

15.verse: They are ravaging Mo’av, attacking its cities; its best young men go down to be slaughtered,” says the king, whose name is ADONAI-Tzva’ot.

16.verse: Mo’av’s ruin is coming soon, its disaster speeds on swiftly.

17.verse: Pity him, all of you who are near him, all of you who know his name; say, “How the mighty scepter is shattered, that splendid staff!”

18.verse: Descend from your glory, and sit in thirst, daughter living in Divon; for Mo’av’s destroyer advances on you; he has destroyed your strongholds.

19.verse: Stand by the road and watch, inhabitant of ‘Aro‘er; ask the man fleeing and the woman escaping, “What is going on?”

20.verse: Mo’av is disgraced, indeed, destroyed. Wail aloud! Shriek! Proclaim it by the Arnon that Mo’av has been laid waste.

21.verse: Judgment has come on the Plain — on Holon, Yachtzah, Mefa‘at,

22.verse: Divon, N’vo, Beit-Diblatayim,

23.verse: Kiryatayim, Beit-Gamul, Beit-M‘on,

24.verse: K’riot, Botzrah and all the cities in the land of Mo’av, far and near.

25.verse: “Mo’av’s strength is cut down, his arm is broken,” says ADONAI.

26.verse: Because Mo’av boasted against ADONAI, make him so drunk that he wallows in his own vomit and becomes a laughingstock.

27.verse: After all, Isra’el was a laughingstock for you. He didn’t associate with thieves; nevertheless, whenever you spoke of him, you shook your head.

28.verse: You who live in Mo’av, leave the cities, and live on the rocks; be like the dove who makes her nest in a hole in the rock at the mouth of a cave.

29.verse: We have heard of the pride of Mo’av: so very proud he is! — presumptuous, proud, conceited; so haughty his heart!

30.verse: “I know what meager ground he has for his arrogance,” says ADONAI. “His boasting has nothing behind it, and it hasn’t accomplished a thing.”

31.verse: Therefore I wail for Mo’av; for all Mo’av I cry; for the people of Kir-Heres I lament.

32.verse: I will weep for you, vineyard of Sivmah, more than I wept for Ya‘zer. Your branches spread to the sea, reaching as far as the sea of Ya‘zer. On your summer fruits and on your vintage the destroyer has fallen.

33.verse: Gladness and joy have been removed from productive fields and the land of Mo’av. “I have stopped the flow of wine from the vats and the shouts of those who tread the grapes — those shouts of joy are stilled.”

34.verse: The cries from Heshbon to El‘aleh are heard as far away as Yachatz; those from Tzo‘ar to Horonayim are heard in ‘Eglat-Shlishiyah; for even the waters of Nimrim have become a desolate waste.

35.verse: “Moreover,” says ADONAI, “in Mo’av I will put an end to anyone sacrificing on a high place or offering incense to his gods.”

36.verse: This is why my heart is moaning for Mo’av like funeral flutes, why my heart moans for the men of Kir-Heres like funeral flutes; for the wealth they produced has vanished.

37.verse: Every head has been shaved bald, every beard has been clipped short, gashes are on every hand, sackcloth around every waist.

38.verse: On all the housetops of Mo’av and in its open places — lamentation everywhere! “For I have broken Mo’av like a pot that nobody wants,” says ADONAI.

39.verse: Wail, “How shattered is Mo’av! How shamefully in retreat!” Thus will Mo’av become an object of ridicule and distress to all its neighbors.

40.verse: For here is what ADONAI says: “Look! Down he swoops like a vulture, spreading his wings against Mo’av —

41.verse: the cities are captured, the strongholds are seized. On that day the hearts of Mo’av’s warriors will be like the heart of a woman in labor.

42.verse: Mo’av will be destroyed as a people, because he boasted against ADONAI.

43.verse: Terror, pit and trap are upon you, people of Mo’av,” says ADONAI.

44.verse: “Whoever flees from the terror will fall into the pit; and he who climbs up out of the pit will be caught in the trap. For I will bring on her, on Mo’av, the year for her punishment,” says ADONAI.

45.verse: “In the shadow of Heshbon the fugitives stop, exhausted. For fire breaks out from Heshbon, a flame from inside Sichon, consuming the sides and tops of the heads of Mo’av’s noisy boasters.

46.verse: Woe to you, Mo’av! K’mosh’s people are doomed! For your sons have been taken captive, and your daughters led into captivity.

47.verse: Yet I will end Mo’av’s exile in the acharit-hayamim,” says ADONAI. This is the judgment on Mo’av.

1.verse: Concerning the people of ‘Amon, here is what ADONAI says: “Has Isra’el no sons? Has he no heir? Then why has Malkam inherited Gad, with his people settled in its cities?

2.verse: Therefore,” says ADONAI, “the days are coming when I will sound the battle alarm against Rabbah and the people of ‘Amon; it will become a tel of ruins, her villages burned to the ground. Then Isra’el will inherit from them who disinherited him,” says ADONAI.

3.verse: “Wail, Heshbon, for ‘Ai is doomed! Cry out, daughters of Rabbah! Wear sackcloth and mourn, running here and there among the sheep pens. For Malkam will go into exile, together with his priests and officers.

4.verse: Why do you take such pride in the valleys, your well-watered valleys, rebellious daughter? You trusted in your riches and thought, ‘Who can attack me?’

5.verse: I am bringing terror on you,” says Adonai ELOHEI-Tzva’ot, “from every side. Each of you will be driven out headlong, with no one to gather the fugitives.

6.verse: But afterwards, I will bring back the exiles of ‘Amon,” says ADONAI.

7.verse: Concerning Edom, this is what ADONAI-Tzva’ot says: “Is there no wisdom left in Teman? Have her wise men forgotten how to counsel? Has their wisdom vanished?

8.verse: Flee! Turn back! Hide yourselves well, you who live in D’dan; for I am bringing calamity on ‘Esav, when the time for me to punish him comes.

9.verse: If grape-pickers came to you, they would leave no grapes for gleaning. If thieves came at night, they would destroy until they were satisfied.

10.verse: So I, for my part, have stripped ‘Esav bare, I have exposed his hiding-places; he will not be able to hide himself. He is doomed — sons, brothers and neighbors — so that he is no more.

11.verse: Leave your orphans; I will keep them alive; let your widows trust in me.”

12.verse: For this is what ADONAI says: “Those who do not deserve to drink from this cup will have to drink it anyway, so should you go unpunished? No, you will not go unpunished; you will certainly drink it.

13.verse: For I have sworn by myself,” says ADONAI, “that Botzrah will become a ruin and an object of astonishment, reproach and cursing; all its cities will be ruins forever.”

14.verse: I have heard a message from ADONAI: “A messenger is sent among the nations, saying: ‘Gather together, and march against her! Prepare for battle!’

15.verse: Here! I will make you least among nations, the most despised of people.

16.verse: Your capacity to terrorize has deceived you and made you arrogant. You make your home in the rocky crags and seize the top of the mountain; but even if you build your nest high as an eagle’s, from there I will drag you down,” says ADONAI.

17.verse: Edom will become an object of horror; everyone passing by will whistle in astonishment at all its disasters.

18.verse: It will be like the overthrow of S’dom, ‘Amora and their neighboring towns,” says ADONAI. “No one will settle there any more, no human being will live there again.

19.verse: It will be like a lion coming up from the thickets of the Yarden against a strong settlement: in an instant I will chase him away and appoint over it whomever I choose. For who is like me? Who can call me to account? What shepherd can stand up to me?”

20.verse: So hear the plan of ADONAI that he has devised against Edom, and his purpose that he will accomplish against those who live in Teman: the least of the flock will drag them away; their own pasture will be in shock at them.

21.verse: The earth quakes at the sound of their fall; their cry can be heard at the Sea of Suf.

22.verse: Like a vulture he will soar, swoop down and spread out his wings against Botzrah. On that day the hearts of Edom’s warriors will be like the heart of a woman in labor.

23.verse: Concerning Dammesek: “Hamat and Arpad are confused; having heard bad news, they dissolve in fear, like the churning sea, which cannot calm itself.

24.verse: Dammesek, weakened, turns to flee; trembling has seized her; anguish and pain take hold of her like the pains of a woman in labor.

25.verse: How can a city so praised be deserted, a city that gave me such joy?

26.verse: Therefore her young men will fall in her squares, and all her warriors be silenced on that day,” says ADONAI-Tzva’ot.

27.verse: “I will light a fire inside Dammesek’s walls which will consume the palaces of Ben-Hadad.”

28.verse: Concerning Kedar and the kingdoms of Hatzor, which N’vukhadretzar king of Bavel struck, ADONAI says: “Set out! March against Kedar! Plunder the people of the east!

29.verse: They will seize their tents and their flocks, their tent curtains and all their equipment; their camels too they will take for themselves and shout at them, ‘Terror in every direction!’

30.verse: Flee! Leave your homes! Hide yourselves well, you who live in Hatzor,” says ADONAI; “for N’vukhadretzar king of Bavel has devised a plan against you; he has formed a scheme against you.

31.verse: Get up! March on a nation at ease, that lives secure,” says ADONAI. “They have neither gates nor bars; they live in isolation.

32.verse: Their camels will be booty, their many cattle a spoil. I will scatter to the winds those who shave the sides of their heads; From every direction I will bring their disaster on them,” says ADONAI.

33.verse: “Hatzor will be a place for jackals to live, desolate forever; no one will settle there any more, no human being will live there again.”

34.verse: This is the word of ADONAI that came to Yirmeyahu the prophet concerning ‘Eilam at the beginning of the reign of Tzidkiyahu king of Y’hudah:

35.verse: “ADONAI-Tzva’ot says: ‘I will break ‘Eilam’s bow, the mainstay of their might.

36.verse: I will bring against ‘Eilam the four winds from the four quarters of the sky and scatter them to all those winds. There will not be one nation to which the dispersed of ‘Eilam will not come.

37.verse: I will break ‘Eilam before their foes, before those who seek their lives; I will bring disaster on them, my burning anger,’ says ADONAI. ‘I will send the sword to pursue them until I have finished them off.

38.verse: I will put my throne in ‘Eilam and destroy their king and leaders,’ says ADONAI.

39.verse: ‘But in the acharit-hayamim, I will bring back the exiles of ‘Eilam,’ says ADONAI.”

1.verse: This is the word which ADONAI spoke concerning Bavel, concerning the land of the Kasdim, through Yirmeyahu the prophet:

2.verse: “Declare it among the nations, proclaim it! Hoist a banner, proclaim it, don’t hide it! Say: ‘Bavel is captured. Bel is shamed, M’rodakh disgraced, her images shamed, her idols disgraced.’

3.verse: For from the north a nation is marching against her that will desolate her land. No one will live there — both humans and animals have fled and gone.

4.verse: In those days, at that time,” says ADONAI, “the people of Isra’el will come, together with the people of Y’hudah. They will weep as they go their way, seeking ADONAI their God.

5.verse: They will ask the way to Tziyon; and, turning their faces toward it, will say, ‘Come, join yourselves to ADONAI by an everlasting covenant never to be forgotten.’

6.verse: My people have been lost sheep. My shepherds made them go astray, turning them loose in the mountains. As they wandered from mountain to hill, they lost track of where their home is.

7.verse: Everyone finding them ate them up. Their enemies said, ‘We aren’t guilty; for they sinned against ADONAI, the resting place of justice; yes, against ADONAI, their ancestors’ hope.’

8.verse: Flee from Bavel! Leave the land of the Kasdim! Be like male goats leading the flock;

9.verse: for I will stir up and bring against Bavel an alliance of great nations from the country to the north. They will array themselves against her; from there she will be captured. Their arrows are like those of a death-dealing warrior; none will return in vain.

10.verse: The land of the Kasdim will be plundered; all who plunder it will get enough,” says ADONAI.

11.verse: “Because you are glad, because you exult, you plunderers of my heritage; because you frisk like a calf in the grass and neigh like stallions;

12.verse: your mother will be utterly shamed, she who bore you will be disgraced. Here she is! — last among the nations, a desert, parched and barren.

13.verse: Because of the anger of ADONAI, no one will live there any more; all of it will be desolate. Everyone passing Bavel will whistle in shock at all her plagues.

14.verse: “Take your positions surrounding Bavel, all you whose bows are strung; shoot at her, spare no arrows; because she sinned against ADONAI.

15.verse: From all sides raise the war cry against her! Now she surrenders! Her buttresses fall, her walls are thrown down, for this is the vengeance of ADONAI. Avenge yourself on her! As she has done, do to her!

16.verse: Cut off the sower from Bavel and the reaper with sickle at harvest-time. For fear of the destroying sword everyone returns to his own people, each one flees to his own land.

17.verse: “Isra’el is a stray lamb, driven away by lions. First to devour him was Ashur’s king; and the last to break his bones is this N’vukhadretzar king of Bavel.”

18.verse: Therefore ADONAI-Tzva’ot, the God of Isra’el, says: “I will punish the king of Bavel and his land as I punished the king of Ashur.

19.verse: I will bring Isra’el back to his pasture, to graze on the Karmel and the Bashan, on the hills of Efrayim and in Gil‘ad until he has his fill.

20.verse: In those days, at that time,” says ADONAI, “Isra’el’s guilt will be sought, but there will be none, and Y’hudah’s sins, but they won’t be found; for I will pardon the remnant I leave.

21.verse: “Attack the land of Meratayim; attack it and those living in P’kod. Waste them, utterly destroy them; do all I have ordered you,” says ADONAI.

22.verse: “The sound of battle is heard in the land, with great destruction!

23.verse: How the hammer of the whole earth lies hacked apart and shattered! What an object of horror among the nations Bavel has become!

24.verse: I set a trap and caught you, Bavel, before you knew it. You were discovered and seized, because you challenged ADONAI.

25.verse: ADONAI has opened his store of arms and brought out the weapons of his wrath; for Adonai ELOHEI-Tzva’ot has work to do in the land of the Kasdim.

26.verse: Attack her from every direction! Open her stores of grain! Pile her up like heaps of grain; destroy her completely; leave nothing!

27.verse: Kill all her bulls! let them go down to be slaughtered! Woe to them! for their day has come, the time for them to be punished.”

28.verse: Hear the sound of the fugitives, of those escaping from Bavel, coming to proclaim in Tziyon the vengeance of ADONAI our God, vengeance over his temple.

29.verse: “Call up archers against Bavel, all whose bows are strung. Besiege her from every side, let no one escape. Repay her for her deeds; as she has done, do to her. For she insulted ADONAI, the Holy One of Isra’el.

30.verse: This is why her young men will fall in her open places, why all her warriors will be silenced on that day,” says ADONAI.

31.verse: “I am against you, arrogant [nation],” says Adonai ELOHEI-Tzva’ot. “For your day has come, the time for you to be punished.

32.verse: The arrogant [nation] will stumble and fall, and no one will lift him up again. I will set his cities on fire, and it will devour everything around him.”

33.verse: Thus says ADONAI-Tzva’ot: “The people of Isra’el are oppressed, and so are the people of Y’hudah. Those who took them captive hold them fast; they refuse to let them go.

34.verse: But their redeemer is strong; ADONAI-Tzva’ot is his name. He will thoroughly plead their cause, so that he can give rest to the land but unrest to those who live in Bavel.

35.verse: ADONAI says, “A sword hangs over the Kasdim, and over those who live in Bavel, over her leaders and over her sages.

36.verse: A sword hangs over the lying diviners; they will become fools. A sword hangs over her warriors; they will be disgraced.

37.verse: A sword hangs over their horses, also over their chariots, also over the foreigners within her; they will become like women. A sword hangs over her treasures; they will be robbed.

38.verse: A drought hangs over her waters; they will be dried up. For this is a land of idols; they go mad over these horrors of theirs.

39.verse: “Therefore wildcats and jackals will live there, and ostriches will settle there. It will never again be peopled, it will be uninhabited age after age;

40.verse: as when God overthrew S’dom, ‘Amora and their neighboring towns,” says ADONAI. “No one will settle there any more, no human being will live there again.

41.verse: “Look! A people is coming from the north; a great nation and many kings are being stirred up from the ends of the earth.

42.verse: They are armed with bow and spear; they are cruel, without compassion; their sound is like the roaring sea, as they ride forth on horses. Their men take their battle positions against you, daughter of Bavel.

43.verse: The king of Bavel has heard news of them; his hands droop, helpless. Anguish seizes hold of him and pain, like a woman in labor.

44.verse: “It will be like a lion coming up from the thickets of the Yarden against a strong settlement; in an instant I will chase him away and appoint over it whomever I choose. For who is like me? Who can call me to account? What shepherd can stand up to me?”

45.verse: So hear the plan of ADONAI that he has devised against Bavel, and his goals that he will accomplish against the land of the Kasdim: the least of the flock will drag them away; their own pasture will be in shock at them.

46.verse: At the sound of Bavel’s capture the earth quakes; their cry is heard throughout the nations.

1.verse: ADONAI says this: “Against Bavel and those living in Lev-Kamai I will stir up a destructive wind.

2.verse: Against Bavel I will send foreigners to winnow her and leave her land empty. They will besiege her from every side on the day of disaster.

3.verse: Let the archer draw his bow, let him flaunt his coat of mail; do not spare her young men, completely destroy her whole army.

4.verse: In the land of the Kasdim the slain will fall, those thrust through [by the sword] in her streets.

5.verse: Isra’el and Y’hudah are not left widowed of their God, ADONAI-Tzva’ot; but the land of [the Kasdim] is full of guilt before the Holy One of Isra’el.”

6.verse: Flee from Bavel, let each one save his life! Don’t perish because of her guilt. For the time has come for the vengeance of ADONAI; he will repay her what she deserves.

7.verse: Bavel was a gold cup in the hands of ADONAI; it made the whole earth drunk — the nations drank her wine; this is why the nations have lost their senses.

8.verse: Bavel has suddenly fallen. She is broken; wail for her. Bring healing ointment for her wounds; perhaps she can be healed.

9.verse: “We tried to heal Bavel, but she cannot be healed. So leave her alone, and each of us will return to his own country.” For the judgment against her rises to the skies and reaches even the clouds.

10.verse: ADONAI has brought forth our victory. Come, let us proclaim in Tziyon the work of ADONAI our God!

11.verse: Sharpen the arrows! Fill the quivers! ADONAI roused the spirit of the kings of the Medes, because he plans to destroy Bavel. This is the vengeance of ADONAI vengeance over his temple.

12.verse: Raise a standard against the walls of Bavel! Strengthen the guard! Post the sentries! Prepare ambushes! For ADONAI has both planned and accomplished what he promised to do to those living in Bavel.

13.verse: You who live near plenty of water, so rich in treasure — your end has come, your time for being cut off!

14.verse: ADONAI-Tzva’ot has sworn by himself, “I will fill you with men as numerous as grasshoppers; they will raise over you a shout of triumph.”

15.verse: He made the earth by his power, established the world by his wisdom spread out the sky by his understanding.

16.verse: When he thunders, the waters in heaven roar, he raises clouds from the ends of the earth, he makes the lightning flash in the rain and brings the wind out from his storehouses.

17.verse: At this, everyone is proved stupid, ignorant, every goldsmith put to shame by his idol! The figures he casts are a fraud, there is no breath in them,

18.verse: they are nothings, ridiculous objects; when the day for their punishment comes, they will perish.

19.verse: Ya‘akov’s portion is not like these, for he is the one who formed all things, including the tribe he claims as his heritage. ADONAI-Tzva’ot is his name.

20.verse: “[Bavel] you are my war club and weapons of war — with you I shatter nations; with you I destroy kingdoms;

21.verse: with you I shatter horses and their riders; with you I shatter chariots and their drivers;

22.verse: with you I shatter husbands and wives; with you I shatter old and young; with you I shatter young men and virgins;

23.verse: with you I shatter shepherds and their flocks; with you I shatter farmers and their teams; with you I shatter governors and deputies.

24.verse: “But I will repay Bavel and all living in the land of the Kasdim for all the evil they did in Tziyon,” says ADONAI, “before your eyes [, Y’hudah].”

25.verse: “I am against you, destructive mountain, destroying all the earth,” says ADONAI. “I will stretch out my hand against you, to send you tumbling down from the crags and make you a burned-out mountain.

26.verse: No one will make cornerstones or foundation-stones from you again; but you will be desolate forever,” says ADONAI.

27.verse: Raise up a banner in the land, blow the shofar among the nations. Prepare the nations for war against her. Summon kingdoms against her — Ararat, Minni and Ashkenaz. Appoint an officer against her; bring up horses like bristling grasshoppers.

28.verse: Prepare the nations against her, the kings of the Medes, his governors and deputies, and all the land he controls.

29.verse: The earth quakes and writhes, as ADONAI’s designs against Bavel are fulfilled, to make the land of Bavel a ruin, with no one living there.

30.verse: Bavel’s warriors have given up fighting; they remain in their fortresses; their courage has failed; they are now like women. Her homes are on fire, her gate-bars broken.

31.verse: One runner runs to meet another, messenger to meet messenger, to report to the king of Bavel that every part of his city is taken,

32.verse: the fords have been occupied, and the swamp thickets set on fire, while the warriors are seized with panic.

33.verse: For here is what ADONAI-Tzva’ot, the God of Isra’el, says: “The daughter of Bavel is like a threshing-floor at treading-time. Just a little while longer, and the time for harvesting her will come.”

34.verse: N’vukhadretzar king of Bavel has devoured me, crushed me. He left me like an empty pot. Like a monster, he swallowed me whole. With my delicacies he stuffed his belly; then he rinsed me out.

35.verse: But one who lives in Tziyon will say, “May my torn flesh be avenged on Bavel”; and Yerushalayim will say, “May my blood be avenged on the Kasdim.”

36.verse: Therefore here is what ADONAI says: “I will plead your cause. I will take vengeance for you. I will dry up her river and make her water sources dry.

37.verse: Bavel will become a heap of ruins, a place for jackals to live, an object of horror and hissing, with no one living there.

38.verse: Together they roar like young lions, growl like lion cubs.

39.verse: When they are hot with desire, I will prepare them a drink. I will make them so drunk they will have convulsions, sleep forever and never wake up,” says ADONAI.

40.verse: “I will drag them down like lambs to be slaughtered, like rams and male goats.”

41.verse: Sheshakh has been captured, the pride of the whole earth seized! Bavel has become an object of horror throughout the nations!

42.verse: The sea has flooded Bavel, overwhelmed her with its raging waves.

43.verse: Her cities have become desolate — parched, arid land, a land where no one lives; nobody even passes through.

44.verse: “I will punish Bel in Bavel and make him disgorge what he swallowed. The nations will no longer flow to him. Bavel’s wall will fall.

45.verse: Get out of her, my people! Each one, save yourself from ADONAI’s furious anger!

46.verse: Don’t be fainthearted, don’t be afraid of the rumors spreading abroad in the land. One year one rumor comes, the next year another one, rumors of violence in the land and rulers fighting rulers.

47.verse: Therefore, listen! The days are coming when I will pass judgment on Bavel’s idols. Her whole land will be put to shame, as all her slain fall on home soil.

48.verse: Then heaven and earth and all that is in them will sing for joy over Bavel; for the plunderers from the north are coming to her,” says ADONAI.

49.verse: Just as Bavel caused the slain of Isra’el to fall, so at Bavel will fall the slain of all the land.

50.verse: You who escaped the sword, go! Don’t stand still! Remember ADONAI from afar, let Yerushalayim come into your minds.

51.verse: “The reproaches we have heard have put us to shame, disgrace covers our faces; because foreigners have entered the sanctuaries of ADONAI’s house.”

52.verse: “Therefore,” says ADONAI, “the days are coming when I will pass judgment on her idols, and the wounded will groan throughout her land.

53.verse: Even if Bavel scales the heavens or reinforces her lofty stronghold, plunderers will come to her from me,” says ADONAI.

54.verse: An agonized cry is heard from Bavel! Great destruction in the land of the Kasdim!

55.verse: For ADONAI is plundering Bavel and silencing her noisy din — their waves roar like the raging ocean, their clamor sounds and resounds.

56.verse: Yes, the plunderer has fallen upon her, fallen on Bavel. Her warriors are captured, their bows are broken. For ADONAI is a God of retribution; he will surely repay.

57.verse: “I will intoxicate her leaders and sages, her governors, deputies and warriors. They will sleep forever and never wake up,” says the king, whose name is ADONAI-Tzva’ot.

58.verse: Thus says ADONAI-Tzva’ot: “The wide walls of Bavel will be razed to the ground, her lofty gates will be set on fire. The peoples are toiling for nothing, the nation’s labor goes up in flames, and everyone is exhausted.”

59.verse: This is the order which Yirmeyahu the prophet gave to S’rayah the son of Neriyah, the son of Machseyah, when he went to Bavel with Tzidkiyahu the king of Y’hudah in the fourth year of his reign. S’rayah was quartermaster.

60.verse: Yirmeyahu had written on a separate scroll all the above words describing the disaster that was to befall Bavel.

61.verse: Yirmeyahu said to S’rayah, “See to it that when you arrive in Bavel you read all these words aloud. Then say,

62.verse: ‘ADONAI, you have promised to destroy this place, that no one will live here, neither human nor animal, but that it will be desolate forever.’

63.verse: When you finish reading this scroll, tie a rock to it, throw it into the middle of the Euphrates,

64.verse: and say, ‘Like this, Bavel will sink, never to rise again, because of the disaster I am bringing on her; and they will grow weary.’” (Up to here, these have been the words of Yirmeyahu.)

1.verse: Tzidkiyahu was twenty-one years old when he began to rule, and he ruled for eleven years in Yerushalayim. His mother’s name was Hamutal the daughter of Yirmeyahu, from Livnah.

2.verse: He did what was evil from ADONAI’s perspective, following the example of everything Y’hoyakim had done.

3.verse: And it was because of ADONAI’s anger that all these things happened to Yerushalayim and Y’hudah, until he had thrown them out of his presence. Tzidkiyahu rebelled against the king of Bavel;

4.verse: so in the ninth year of his reign, in the tenth month, on the tenth day of the month, N’vukhadretzar king of Bavel marched against Yerushalayim with his entire army. He set up camp against it and built siege towers against it on every side.

5.verse: The city remained under siege into the eleventh year of King Tzidkiyahu.

6.verse: On the ninth day of the fourth month, when the famine in the city was so severe that there was no food for the people of the land,

7.verse: they broke through into the city. All the soldiers fled and left the city by night through the gate between the two walls, near the king’s garden. Because the Kasdim were surrounding the city, they took the route through the ‘Aravah.

8.verse: But the army of the Kasdim went in pursuit of the king and overtook Tzidkiyahu on the plains near Yericho; all his troops deserted him.

9.verse: Then they took the king and brought him up to the king of Bavel in Rivlah, in the land of Hamat, where he passed judgment on him.

10.verse: The king of Bavel slaughtered his sons before his eyes; he also slaughtered all the leading men of Y’hudah in Rivlah.

11.verse: Then the king of Bavel put out Tzidkiyahu’s eyes, bound him in chains, carried him off to Bavel and kept him in prison until the day of his death.

12.verse: In the fifth month, on the tenth day of the month, which was also the nineteenth year of King N’vukhadretzar, king of Bavel, N’vuzar’adan, the commander of the guard and a close associate of the king of Bavel, entered Yerushalayim.

13.verse: He burned down the house of ADONAI, the royal palace and all the houses in Yerushalayim — every notable person’s house he burned to the ground.

14.verse: The whole army of the Kasdim, who were with the commander of the guard, broke down all the walls of Yerushalayim on every side.

15.verse: N’vuzar’adan the commander of the guard then deported some of the poor people, the remaining population of the city, the deserters who had defected to the king of Bavel and the rest of the common people.

16.verse: But N’vuzar’adan the commander of the guard left behind some of the poor people of the land to be vineyard-workers and farmers.

17.verse: The Kasdim smashed the bronze columns of the house of ADONAI, also the trolleys and bronze Sea that were in the house of ADONAI, and carried their bronze to Bavel.

18.verse: They also took away the pots, shovels, snuffers, basins, pans, and all the bronze articles they had used in worship.

19.verse: The commander of the guard took the cups, censers, sprinkling bowls, pots, menorahs, pans and bowls — everything made of gold and everything made of silver.

20.verse: The bronze in the two columns, the one Sea, and the twelve bronze bulls under the bases, all of which Shlomo had made for the house of ADONAI, was more than could be weighed.

21.verse: As for the columns, the height of one column was thirty-one-and-a-half feet; it took a twenty-one-foot measuring line to go around it; and its thickness was four fingers — it was hollow.

22.verse: On it was a capital of brass eight-and-three quarters feet high, with netting and pomegranates all around the capital, all of bronze; the second column was similar, also with pomegranates.

23.verse: There were ninety-six pomegranates on the outside; while the total number of pomegranates in the netting was one hundred.

24.verse: The commander of the guard took [prisoner] S’rayah the chief cohen, Tz’fanyah the second-ranking cohen, and three doorkeepers.

25.verse: From the city he took an official in charge of the soldiers, seven close associates of the king who had been found in the city, the army commander’s secretary in charge of military conscription, and sixty of the common people found inside the city.

26.verse: N’vuzar’adan the commander of the guard took them and brought them to the king of Bavel in Rivlah.

27.verse: There in Rivlah, in the land of Hamat, the king of Bavel had them put to death. Thus Y’hudah was carried away captive out of his land.

28.verse: The numbers of people deported by N’vukhadretzar were as follows: in the seventh year, 3,023 persons from Y’hudah;

29.verse: in the eighteenth year of N’vukhadretzar, 832 persons from Yerushalayim;

30.verse: and in the twenty-third year of N’vukhadretzar, N’vuzar’adan the commander of the guard deported 745 persons from Y’hudah; the total comes to 4,600 persons.

31.verse: In the thirty-seventh year of the captivity of Y’hoyakhin king of Y’hudah, in the twelfth month, on the twenty-fifth day of the month, Eveel-M’rodakh began his reign as king of Bavel; and in his first year, he commuted the sentence of Y’hoyakhin king of Y’hudah and released him from prison.

32.verse: He treated him with kindness and gave him a throne higher than those of the other kings there with him in Bavel.

33.verse: So Y’hoyakhin no longer had to wear prison clothes; moreover, he was provided with food as long as he lived,

34.verse: and he was granted a daily allowance by the king of Bavel to spend on his other needs for as long as he lived, until the day of his death.
